text:
Apologies if everyone already knows about this. But just found this PS plugin for grid drawing. And I like it. 

Something tells me I've been told about it before but didn't pay attention until now: <http://guideguide.me/>

attachments.text: GuideGuide an extension for Adobe Photoshop that makes it easy to place guides and create grids in your document or selection.
attachments.fallback: GuideGuide an extension for Adobe Photoshop that makes it easy to place guides and create grids in your document or selection.

text: I've always used this <http://960.gs|960.gs> grid system I learned about in school but it was just template pages at fixed widths. This is infinitely better.
I love GG but making grids inside PS takes for ever and I can't always trust GG
i usually use <http://gridulator.com/> to do the calculations

attachments.text: A quick and easy grid calculator for pixel pros (and novices).
attachments.fallback: A quick and easy grid calculator for pixel pros (and novices).

text: and then type those values into guideguide
yeah the one bad thing about guideguide is that sometime sguides just move (not the plugin's fault, the user's fault.
The other thing is that I like my guides to be guides not a grid. I know that's more of a PS limitation than GG's fault.
although the most recent version of guideguide allows you to save settings so its less of an issue
Hm, interesting. All very interesting. These are good things to know about.
Embarrassing question: Is there an equivalent to Photoshop's smart objects in illustrator?
I know fireworks has the idea of objects and I thought AI had something similar.
but i dont use illustrator for much besides drawing
